Package com.mitsuki.jmatrix.exception

Class JMatrixBaseException

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Throwable
      • java.lang.Exception
        • java.lang.RuntimeException
          • com.mitsuki.jmatrix.exception.JMatrixBaseException
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    IllegalMatrixSizeException, InvalidIndexException, MatrixArrayFullException, NullMatrixException
    public class JMatrixBaseException
extends RuntimeException
    Base exception class for all JMatrix exceptions. This exception and its subclasses are unchecked exceptions, which means they can be thrown during runtime without being explicitly caught or declared.

    The class JMatrixBaseException serves as a foundational exception that can be used in a matrix-related context. It provides a consistent interface for handling errors and can wrap other exceptions, allowing for a more flexible and unified error-handling strategy across the JMatrix library.

    Type: Unchecked exception

    As of version 1.5.0, a new capability has been introduced to configure the behavior of auto-raised exceptions either using an environment variable or system property. This feature allows applications to determine whether exceptions should be automatically raised and cause the application to exit, or if they should be thrown and handled via traditional try-catch blocks. This flexibility is crucial for scenarios where different environments or phases of development might require different error-handling approaches.

    Configure Auto-raise Behavior:

    The behavior is controlled by setting either the system property "jm.autoraise" or the environment variable "jm_autoraise". The configuration options are as follows:

    • If the auto-raise configuration either from the system property ("jm.autoraise") or environment variable ("jm_autoraise") is set to manual or no, the exceptions will be thrown, enabling traditional error handling through try-catch blocks.
    • If the auto-raise configuration either from the system property ("jm.autoraise") or environment variable ("jm_autoraise") is set to auto or yes, or if it is undefined or an empty string, the exceptions will be auto-raised. This means the stack trace of the exception will be printed, and the application will exit immediately with the specified error code. This is useful for environments where immediate feedback is necessary, such as in development or testing phases.

    If the auto-raise configuration is set using both environment variables and system properties, the system property will take precedence.

    This enhancement offers greater control over exception handling, making the JMatrix library more adaptable to various use cases and environments. It ensures that developers can choose the most appropriate error-handling strategy based on their specific needs.

    It is RECOMMENDED to set the configuration using system property. Here is an example usage to set the "jm.autoraise" configuration using system property from command-line. 

     
   $ java -D"jm.autoraise"=manual -cp /path/to/jmatrix-<VERSION>.jar Foo.java

    And this is an example usage to set the "jm.autoraise" configuration at runtime. 

     
   // Set the environment variable to configure behavior
   System.setProperty("jm.autoraise", "manual");
   try {
      // Some matrix-related operations that might throw
      // JMatrixBaseException or its subclasses
   } catch (JMatrixBaseException e) {
      // Handle exception
   }
    Since:
    1.0.0b.1

      • JMatrixBaseException

        public JMatrixBaseException​(Throwable cause)
        Constructs a new JMatrixBaseException with the specified cause.

        This constructor allows for exception chaining, where the new exception is caused by an existing throwable. This is useful for wrapping lower-level exceptions in higher-level exceptions, providing more context about the error that occurred.

        The detailed message for the new exception is derived from the cause:

        • If the cause is not null, the detailed message is obtained by calling cause.toString(), which typically includes the class name and the message of the cause.
        • If the cause is null, the detailed message for the new exception is set to null.

        Additionally, this constructor attempts to propagate the error code from the cause to the new exception:

        • If the cause is an instance of JMatrixBaseException or a subclass thereof, the error code is retrieved using getErrorCode() and set for the new exception.
        • If the cause is not an instance of JMatrixBaseException, the error code for the new exception is set to UNKERR (Unknown error).
        Since:
        1.0.0b.1
        Parameters:
        cause - The cause of this exception. A null value is permitted and indicates that the cause is nonexistent or unknown.

      • JMatrixBaseException

        public JMatrixBaseException​(String s,
                            Throwable cause)
        Constructs a new JMatrixBaseException with the specified cause and a detailed message for later retrieval by getMessage().

        This constructor allows for exception chaining, where the new exception is caused by an existing throwable. This is useful for wrapping lower-level exceptions in higher-level exceptions, providing more context about the error that occurred.

        Additionally, this constructor attempts to propagate the error code from the cause to the new exception:

        • If the cause is an instance of JMatrixBaseException or a subclass thereof, the error code is retrieved using getErrorCode() and set for the new exception.
        • If the cause is not an instance of JMatrixBaseException, the error code for the new exception is set to UNKERR (Unknown error).
        Since:
        1.5.0
        Parameters:
        s - The descriptive message.
        cause - The cause of this exception. A null value is permitted and indicates that the cause is nonexistent or unknown.

      • JMatrixBaseException

        protected JMatrixBaseException​(String message,
                               Throwable cause,
                               boolean enableSuppression,
                               boolean writableStackTrace)
        Constructs a new JMatrixBaseException with the specified detail message, cause, suppression enabled or disabled, and writable stack trace enabled or disabled.

        The detail message is saved for later retrieval by the getMessage() method. If cause is not null, the error code will be determined based on whether the cause is an instance of JMatrixBaseException of its subclasses. If it is, the error code will be inherited from the cause; otherwise, the error code will be set to JMErrorCode.UNKERR.

        Since:
        1.5.0
        Parameters:
        message - The detail message (which is saved for later retrieval by the getMessage() method)
        cause - The cause (which is saved for later retrieval by the getCause() method). A null value is permitted, and indicates that the cause is nonexistent or unknown.
        enableSuppression - Whether or not suppression is enabled or disabled.
        writableStackTrace - Whether or not the stack trace should be writable.

    • Method Detail

      • printStackTrace

        public void printStackTrace()
        Prints this throwable and its backtrace to the standard error stream (System.err).

        The format of this information depends on the implementation, but the following example may be regarded as typical: 

         
 /!\ EXCEPTION
 >>>>>>>>>>>>>
 com.mitsuki.jmatrix.exception.InvalidIndexException [INVIDX]: Given row index is out of bounds
         at "Example.main" -> "Example.java": line 7
         ...

 [EXCEPTION INFO]
 Type: com.mitsuki.jmatrix.exception.InvalidIndexException
 Code: INVIDX
 Message: Given row index is out of bounds

        Output above was produced by this code: 

         
   public class Example {
      public static void main(String[] args) {
          Matrix m = new Matrix(new double[][] {
              { 10, 10, 10 },
              { 20, 20, 20 }
          });
          m = m.dropRow(3);  // Throws
      }
   }
        Overrides:
        printStackTrace in class Throwable
        Since:
        1.0.0b.1

      • isAutoRaise

        public static boolean isAutoRaise()
        Checks whether the current value of auto-raise configuration is set to auto.
        Since:
        1.5.0
        Returns:
        true if the auto-raise configuration is set to auto. Otherwise, returns false.
        Implementation Note:
        The method is synchronized to ensure thread safety.

      • raise

        public static void raise​(RuntimeException cause)
        Raises an exception based on the specified cause, with an automatically determined error number.

        This method provides a mechanism to either print the stack trace of a given exception and exit the application with a specified error code, or throw the exception, depending on the configuration set by the "jm.autoraise" environment variable. The error number is determined based on the type of the provided exception.

        If the isAutoRaise() method returns true, indicating that the "jm.autoraise" environment variable is set to auto:

        • The stack trace of the provided exception cause is printed to the standard error stream.
        • The application then exits with the determined error number.
        • An error message indicating the exit code is printed to the standard error stream (System.err).

        If the isAutoRaise() returns false, the provided exception cause is thrown, allowing it to propagate up the call stack. This behavior supports scenarios where the application prefers to handle exceptions using traditional try-catch blocks rather than exiting.

        The error number is determined as follows:

        • If the provided cause is either of an instance of JMatrixBaseException or a subclass thereof, the error number is retrieved using the cause.getErrorCode().getErrno() method.
        • If the provided cause is not an instance of JMatrixBaseException, the error number is set to UNKERR (Unknown error), which corresponds to the error code 400.
        Since:
        1.5.0
        Parameters:
        cause - The runtime exception that caused the error. This exception will either be printed and cause the application to exit, or will be thrown based on the configuration.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - If the auto-raise configuration is not set to auto, the method throws the provided exception cause.
        See Also:
        raise(RuntimeException, int)

      • raise

        public static void raise​(RuntimeException cause,
                         int errno)
        Raises an exception based on the specified cause and error number.

        This method provides a mechanism to either print the stack trace of a given exception and exit the application with a specified error code, or throw the exception, depending on the configuration set by the "jm.autoraise" environment variable. This allows for configurable error handling that can be controlled through environment settings.

        It will checks whether the auto-raise configuration is set to auto utilizing the isAutoRaise() method, if the isAutoRaise() method returns true, indicating that the auto-raise configuration is set to auto:

        • The stack trace of the provided exception cause is printed to the standard error stream.
        • The application then exits with the specified error number errno. If errno is less than Integer.MIN_VALUE (-2147483648), it is set to Integer.MIN_VALUE to ensure it is within valid range.
        • An error message indicating the exit code is printed to the standard error stream.

        If isAutoRaise() returns false, the provided exception cause is thrown, allowing it to propagate up the call stack. This behavior supports scenarios where the application prefers to handle exceptions using traditional try-catch blocks rather than exiting.

        Since:
        1.5.0
        Parameters:
        cause - The runtime exception that caused the error. This exception will either be printed and cause the application to exit, or will be thrown based on the configuration.
        errno - The error number to exit with if auto-raise is enabled. This number should be a valid integer within the range Integer.MIN_VALUE to Integer.MAX_VALUE. If the provided value is less than Integer.MIN_VALUE, it will be adjusted to Integer.MIN_VALUE.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - If the auto-raise configuration is not set to auto, the method throws the provided exception cause.
        See Also:
        raise(RuntimeException)
